posts.name: Mohammed
posts.cooked:
how can we program a 3-pin (R,G,B) LED strip connected to the PWM ?

is there a class that we can use?

posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked: I recommend looking into the AddressableLEDs class. Addressable LEDs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

link_counts.title: Addressable LEDs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Mohammed
posts.cooked: the problem is that the AddressableLED class only uses one port, we have 3 ports, R G and B

posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked: Ahh, interesting, I will try to look into it

posts.name: David B
posts.cooked: Got a pic of the wires?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
To directly control 3 sets of led’s, circuitry is needed to use the PWM signal to adjust how much power is transmitted into the strip.

The Rev Blinkin is one example of such hardware. Custom circutry could also be used.

link_counts.title: Driving LED with an N-channel MOSFET - Electrical Engineering Stack Exchange

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
Mohammed:

the problem is that the AddressableLED class only uses one port, we have 3 ports, R G and B

An important distinction to make is that the one wire with ARGB LEDS is a signal wire and can come directly from the RoboRIO, however with “dumb” RGB strips those 3 wires are the actual power wires supplying the LEDs which cannot be fed directly from the RoboRIO.

What you need at a minimum is an LED amplifier such as this: https://a.co/d/90vfAKD

Then in code it should be as simple as setting the R, G, and B ports to output the desired duty cycle.

link_counts.title: Confused on how to program/wire RGB LED Strip

posts.cooked:
Having programmed dozens of WS2812 LED strips, I can confidently say that I have never had to worry about writing any low-level, timing-dependent code to manipulate serial bitstreams.

I really find it strange that LED strips are one of the most over-complicated topics discussed here on CD . There are at least 4 common ways to put LEDs on a robot. None of them avoid the need for some kind of voltage regulator. Some of them are dependent on the addition of an expensive LED controller that is (IMHO) no easier to program than directly addressing the LED strip with the built-in WPILib support.

If the most complicated part of putting LEDs on your robot ISN’T deciding when to run which light patterns in your code, then you are doing it wrong. It should take no more than 20 - 30 minutes to code up the basic LED subsystem regardless of what solution you choose.

“Gimme volts I glow” is a gross oversimplification of what is required to get an RGB strip to do anything really useful. At minimum, you need a 3-channel PWM driver (unless you’re running a really short strip)  and then you need code to control 3 PWM channels on the Rio to effect color changes. And then the strip is still limited to being all the same color.

Or sure, just “give it volts.” It will glow. In one color. For the entire match. Or maybe it will just let out the magic smoke, depending on the volts.

I honestly don’t know how students navigate the mountains of conflicting opinions on LED lighting here to ever get this working at all.
